<Sent id="1890">
	Text = "CHAPTER VIII."
</Sent>
<Sent id="1891">
	Text = "Monseigneur in the Country A beautiful landscape, with the corn bright in it, but not abundant."
</Sent>
<Sent id="1892">
	Text = "Patches of poor rye where corn should have been, patches of poor peas and beans, patches of most coarse vegetable substitutes for wheat."
</Sent>
<Sent id="1893">
	Text = "On inanimate nature, as on the men and women who cultivated it, a prevalent tendency towards an appearance of vegetating unwillingly-- a dejected disposition to give up, and wither away."
</Sent>
<Sent id="1894">
	Text = "Monsieur the Marquis in his travelling carriage which might have been lighter, conducted by four post-horses and two postilions, fagged up a steep hill."
</Sent>
<Sent id="1895">
	Text = "A blush on the countenance of Monsieur the Marquis was no impeachment of his high breeding it was not from within it was occasioned by an external circumstance beyond his control-- the setting sun."
</Sent>
<Sent id="1896">
	Text = "The sunset struck so brilliantly into the travelling carriage when it gained the hill-top, that its occupant was steeped in crimson."
</Sent>
<Sent id="1897">
	Text = "“It will die out,” said Monsieur the Marquis, glancing at his hands, “directly."
</Sent>
<Sent id="1898">
	Text = "” In effect, the sun was so low that it dipped at the moment."
</Sent>
<Sent id="1899">
	Text = "When the heavy drag had been adjusted to the wheel, and the carriage slid down hill, with a cinderous smell, in a cloud of dust, the red glow departed quickly the sun and the Marquis going down together, there was no glow left when the drag was taken off."
</Sent>
<Sent id="1900">
	Text = "But, there remained a broken country, bold and open, a little village at the bottom of the hill, a broad sweep and rise beyond it, a church-tower, a windmill, a forest for the chase, and a crag with a fortress on it used as a prison."
</Sent>
<Sent id="1901">
	Text = "Round upon all these darkening objects as the night drew on, the Marquis looked, with the air of one who was coming near home."
</Sent>
<Sent id="1902">
	Text = "The village had its one poor street, with its poor brewery, poor tannery, poor tavern, poor stable-yard for relays of post-horses, poor fountain, all usual poor appointments."
</Sent>
<Sent id="1903">
	Text = "It had its poor people too."
</Sent>
<Sent id="1904">
	Text = "All its people were poor, and many of them were sitting at their doors, shredding spare onions and the like for supper, while many were at the fountain, washing leaves, and grasses, and any such small yieldings of the earth that could be eaten."
</Sent>
<Sent id="1905">
	Text = "Expressive signs of what made them poor, were not wanting the tax for the state, the tax for the church, the tax for the lord, tax local and tax general, were to be paid here and to be paid there, according to solemn inscription in the little village, until the wonder was, that there was any village left unswallowed."
</Sent>
<Sent id="1906">
	Text = "Few children were to be seen, and no dogs."
</Sent>
<Sent id="1907">
	Text = "As to the men and women, their choice on earth was stated in the prospect-- Life on the lowest terms that could sustain it, down in the little village under the mill or captivity and Death in the dominant prison on the crag."

<Sent id="2573">
	Text = "The Fellow of No Delicacy If Sydney Carton ever shone anywhere, he certainly never shone in the house of Doctor Manette."

<Sent id="3268">
	Text = "CHAPTER XVII."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3269">
	Text = "One Night Never did the sun go down with a brighter glory on the quiet corner in Soho, than one memorable evening when the Doctor and his daughter sat under the plane-tree together."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3270">
	Text = "Never did the moon rise with a milder radiance over great London, than on that night when it found them still seated under the tree, and shone upon their faces through its leaves."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3271">
	Text = "Lucie was to be married to-morrow."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3272">
	Text = "She had reserved this last evening for her father, and they sat alone under the plane-tree."

	Text = "“You are happy, my dear father?"
</Sent>

	Text = "” “Quite, my child."

	Text = "” They had said little, though they had been there a long time."

<Sent id="3276">
	Text = "When it was yet light enough to work and read, she had neither engaged herself in her usual work, nor had she read to him."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3277">
	Text = "She had employed herself in both ways, at his side under the tree, many and many a time but, this time was not quite like any other, and nothing could make it so."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3278">
	Text = "“And I am very happy to-night, dear father."

<Sent id="3280">

<Sent id="3281">
	Text = "Even as it is--” Even as it was, she could not command her voice."

<Sent id="3283">

	Text = "“Dearest dear! Can you tell me, this last time, that you feel quite, quite sure, no new affections of mine, and no new duties of mine, will ever interpose between us?"

	Text = "“See Defarge!” She stood immovable close to the grim old officer, and remained immovable close to him remained immovable close to him through the streets, as Defarge and the rest bore him along remained immovable close to him when he was got near his destination, and began to be struck at from behind remained immovable close to him when the long-gathering rain of stabs and blows fell heavy was so close to him when he dropped dead under it, that, suddenly animated, she put her foot upon his neck, and with her cruel knife-- long ready-- hewed off his head."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3859">
	Text = "The hour was come, when Saint Antoine was to execute his horrible idea of hoisting up men for lamps to show what he could be and do."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3860">
	Text = "Saint Antoine=s blood was up, and the blood of tyranny and domination by the iron hand was down-- down on the steps of the Hotel de Ville where the governor=s body lay-- down on the sole of the shoe of Madame Defarge where she had trodden on the body to steady it for mutilation."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3861">
	Text = "“Lower the lamp yonder!” cried Saint Antoine, after glaring round for a new means of death “here is one of his soldiers to be left on guard!” The swinging sentinel was posted, and the sea rushed on."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3862">
	Text = "The sea of black and threatening waters, and of destructive upheaving of wave against wave, whose depths were yet unfathomed and whose forces were yet unknown."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3863">
	Text = "The remorseless sea of turbulently swaying shapes, voices of vengeance, and faces hardened in the furnaces of suffering until the touch of pity could make no mark on them."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3864">
	Text = "But, in the ocean of faces where every fierce and furious expression was in vivid life, there were two groups of faces-- each seven in number-- so fixedly contrasting with the rest, that never did sea roll which bore more memorable wrecks with it."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3865">
	Text = "Seven faces of prisoners, suddenly released by the storm that had burst their tomb, were carried high overhead all scared, all lost, all wondering and amazed, as if the Last Day were come, and those who rejoiced around them were lost spirits."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3866">
	Text = "Other seven faces there were, carried higher, seven dead faces, whose drooping eyelids and half-seen eyes awaited the Last Day Impassive faces, yet with a suspended-- not an abolished-- expression on them faces, rather, in a fearful pause, as having yet to raise the dropped lids of the eyes, and bear witness with the bloodless lips, “THOU DIDST IT!” Seven prisoners released, seven gory heads on pikes, the keys of the accursed fortress of the eight strong towers, some discovered letters and other memorials of prisoners of old time, long dead of broken hearts,-- such, and such-- like, the loudly echoing footsteps of Saint Antoine escort through the Paris streets in mid-July, one thousand seven hundred and eighty-nine."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3867">
	Text = "Now, Heaven defeat the fancy of Lucie Darnay, and keep these feet far out of her life! For, they are headlong, mad, and dangerous and in the years so long after the breaking of the cask at Defarge=s wine-shop door, they are not easily purified when once stained red."
</Sent>

	Text = "The Sea Still Rises Haggard Saint Antoine had had only one exultant week, in which to soften his modicum of hard and bitter bread to such extent as he could, with the relish of fraternal embraces and congratulations, when Madame Defarge sat at her counter, as usual, presiding over the customers."

	Text = "Villain Foulon taken, my sister! Old Foulon taken, my mother! Miscreant Foulon taken, my daughter! Foulon who told my old father that he might eat grass, when I had no bread to give him! Foulon who told my baby it might suck grass, when these breasts were dry with want! O mother of God, this Foulon! O Heaven our suffering! Hear me, my dead baby and my withered father I swear on my knees, on these stones, to avenge you on Foulon! Husbands, and brothers, and young men, Give us the blood of Foulon, Give us the head of Foulon, Give us the heart of Foulon, Give us the body and soul of Foulon, Rend Foulon to pieces, and dig him into the ground, that grass may grow from him! 	Text = "Defarge had but sprung over a railing and a table, and folded the miserable wretch in a deadly embrace-- Madame Defarge had but followed and turned her hand in one of the ropes with which he was tied-- The Vengeance and Jacques Three were not yet up with them, and the men at the windows had not yet swooped into the Hall, like birds of prey from their high perches-- when the cry seemed to go up, all over the city, “Bring him out! <Sent id="3939">
	Text = "CHAPTER XXIII."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3940">
	Text = "Fire Rises There was a change on the village where the fountain fell, and where the mender of roads went forth daily to hammer out of the stones on the highway such morsels of bread as might serve for patches to hold his poor ignorant soul and his poor reduced body together."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3941">
	Text = "The prison on the crag was not so dominant as of yore there were soldiers to guard it, but not many there were officers to guard the soldiers, but not one of them knew what his men would do-- beyond this that it would probably not be what he was ordered."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3942">
	Text = "Far and wide lay a ruined country, yielding nothing but desolation."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3943">
	Text = "Every green leaf, every blade of grass and blade of grain, was as shrivelled and poor as the miserable people."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3944">
	Text = "Everything was bowed down, dejected, oppressed, and broken."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3945">
	Text = "Habitations, fences, domesticated animals, men, women, children, and the soil that bore them-- all worn out."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3946">
	Text = "Monseigneur often a most worthy individual gentleman was a national blessing, gave a chivalrous tone to things, was a polite example of luxurious and shining life, and a great deal more to equal purpose nevertheless, Monseigneur as a class had, somehow or other, brought things to this."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3947">
	Text = "Strange that Creation, designed expressly for Monseigneur, should be so soon wrung dry and squeezed out! There must be something short-sighted in the eternal arrangements, surely! Thus it was, however and the last drop of blood having been extracted from the flints, and the last screw of the rack having been turned so often that its purchase crumbled, and it now turned and turned with nothing to bite, Monseigneur began to run away from a phenomenon so low and unaccountable."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3948">
	Text = "But, this was not the change on the village, and on many a village like it."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3949">
	Text = "For scores of years gone by, Monseigneur had squeezed it and wrung it, and had seldom graced it with his presence except for the pleasures of the chase-- now, found in hunting the people now, found in hunting the beasts, for whose preservation Monseigneur made edifying spaces of barbarous and barren wilderness."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3950">
	Text = "No The change consisted in the appearance of strange faces of low caste, rather than in the disappearance of the high caste, chiselled, and otherwise beautified and beautifying features of Monseigneur."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3951">
	Text = "For, in these times, as the mender of roads worked, solitary, in the dust, not often troubling himself to reflect that dust he was and to dust he must return, being for the most part too much occupied in thinking how little he had for supper and how much more he would eat if he had it-- in these times, as he raised his eyes from his lonely labour, and viewed the prospect, he would see some rough figure approaching on foot, the like of which was once a rarity in those parts, but was now a frequent presence."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3952">
	Text = "As it advanced, the mender of roads would discern without surprise, that it was a shaggy-haired man, of almost barbarian aspect, tall, in wooden shoes that were clumsy even to the eyes of a mender of roads, grim, rough, swart, steeped in the mud and dust of many highways, dank with the marshy moisture of many low grounds, sprinkled with the thorns and leaves and moss of many byways through woods."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3953">
	Text = "Such a man came upon him, like a ghost, at noon in the July weather, as he sat on his heap of stones under a bank, taking such shelter as he could get from a shower of hail."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3954">
	Text = "The man looked at him, looked at the village in the hollow, at the mill, and at the prison on the crag."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3955">
	Text = "When he had identified these objects in what benighted mind he had, he said, in a dialect that was just intelligible “How goes it, Jacques?"
</Sent>
<Sent id="3956">
	Text = "” “All well, Jacques."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3957">
	Text = "” “Touch then!” They joined hands, and the man sat down on the heap of stones."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3958">
	Text = "“No dinner?"
</Sent>
<Sent id="3959">
	Text = "” “Nothing but supper now,” said the mender of roads, with a hungry face."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3960">
	Text = "“It is the fashion,” growled the man."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3961">
	Text = "“I meet no dinner anywhere."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3962">
	Text = "” He took out a blackened pipe, filled it, lighted it with flint and steel, pulled at it until it was in a bright glow then, suddenly held it from him and dropped something into it from between his finger and thumb, that blazed and went out in a puff of smoke."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3963">
	Text = "“Touch then."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3964">
	Text = "” It was the turn of the mender of roads to say it this time, after observing these operations."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3965">
	Text = "They again joined hands."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3966">
	Text = "“To-night?"
</Sent>
<Sent id="3967">
	Text = "” said the mender of roads."

<Sent id="3968">

	Text = "“Where?"
</Sent>
<Sent id="3970">
	Text = "” “Here."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3971">

<Sent id="3972">
	Text = "“Show me!” said the traveller then, moving to the brow of the hill."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3973">
	Text = "“See!” returned the mender of roads, with extended finger."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3974">
	Text = "“You go down here, and straight through the street, and past the fountain--” “To the Devil with all that!” interrupted the other, rolling his eye over the landscape."

<Sent id="3975">
	Text = "“I go through no streets and past no fountains."

<Sent id="3976">
	Text = "Well?"
</Sent>

	Text = "” “Well! About two leagues beyond the summit of that hill above the village."

<Sent id="3978">
	Text = "” “Good."

<Sent id="3979">
	Text = "When do you cease to work?"

<Sent id="3980">

</Sent>
<Sent id="3982">
	Text = "I have walked two nights without resting."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3983">

</Sent>
<Sent id="3984">
	Text = "Will you wake me?"
</Sent>
<Sent id="3985">
	Text = "” “Surely."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3986">
	Text = "” The wayfarer smoked his pipe out, put it in his breast, slipped off his great wooden shoes, and lay down on his back on the heap of stones."

<Sent id="3987">
	Text = "He was fast asleep directly."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3988">
	Text = "As the road-mender plied his dusty labour, and the hail-clouds, rolling away, revealed bright bars and streaks of sky which were responded to by silver gleams upon the landscape, the little man who wore a red cap now, in place of his blue one seemed fascinated by the figure on the heap of stones."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3989">
	Text = "His eyes were so often turned towards it, that he used his tools mechanically, and, one would have said, to very poor account."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3990">
	Text = "The bronze face, the shaggy black hair and beard, the coarse woollen red cap, the rough medley dress of home-spun stuff and hairy skins of beasts, the powerful frame attenuated by spare living, and the sullen and desperate compression of the lips in sleep, inspired the mender of roads with awe."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3991">
	Text = "The traveller had travelled far, and his feet were footsore, and his ankles chafed and bleeding his great shoes, stuffed with leaves and grass, had been heavy to drag over the many long leagues, and his clothes were chafed into holes, as he himself was into sores."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3992">
	Text = "Stooping down beside him, the road-mender tried to get a peep at secret weapons in his breast or where not but, in vain, for he slept with his arms crossed upon him, and set as resolutely as his lips."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3993">
	Text = "Fortified towns with their stockades, guard-houses, gates, trenches, and drawbridges, seemed to the mender of roads, to be so much air as against this figure."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3994">
	Text = "And when he lifted his eyes from it to the horizon and looked around, he saw in his small fancy similar figures, stopped by no obstacle, tending to centres all over France."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3995">
	Text = "The man slept on, indifferent to showers of hail and intervals of brightness, to sunshine on his face and shadow, to the paltering lumps of dull ice on his body and the diamonds into which the sun changed them, until the sun was low in the west, and the sky was glowing."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3996">
	Text = "Then, the mender of roads having got his tools together and all things ready to go down into the village, roused him."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3997">
	Text = "“Good!” said the sleeper, rising on his elbow."
</Sent>
<Sent id="3998">
	Text = "“Two leagues beyond the summit of the hill?"
</Sent>
<Sent id="3999">
	Text = "” “About."
</Sent>
<Sent id="4000">
	Text = "” “About."
</Sent>
<Sent id="4001">
	Text = "Good!” The mender of roads went home, with the dust going on before him according to the set of the wind, and was soon at the fountain, squeezing himself in among the lean kine brought there to drink, and appearing even to whisper to them in his whispering to all the village."
</Sent>
<Sent id="4002">
	Text = "When the village had taken its poor supper, it did not creep to bed, as it usually did, but came out of doors again, and remained there."
</Sent>
<Sent id="4003">

<Sent id="4043">
	Text = "Drawn to the Loadstone Rock In such risings of fire and risings of sea-- the firm earth shaken by the rushes of an angry ocean which had now no ebb, but was always on the flow, higher and higher, to the terror and wonder of the beholders on the shore-- three years of tempest were consumed."

	Text = "The shining Bull=s Eye of the Court was gone, or it would have been the mark for a hurricane of national bullets."

<Sent id="4237">
	Text = "The traveller fared slowly on his way, who fared towards Paris from England in the autumn of the year one thousand seven hundred and ninety-two."
</Sent>
<Sent id="4238">
	Text = "More than enough of bad roads, bad equipages, and bad horses, he would have encountered to delay him, though the fallen and unfortunate King of France had been upon his throne in all his glory but, the changed times were fraught with other obstacles than these."

<Sent id="4239">
	Text = "Every town-gate and village taxing-house had its band of citizen-patriots, with their national muskets in a most explosive state of readiness, who stopped all comers and goers, cross-questioned them, inspected their papers, looked for their names in lists of their own, turned them back, or sent them on, or stopped them and laid them in hold, as their capricious judgment or fancy deemed best for the dawning Republic One and Indivisible, of Liberty, Equality, Fraternity, or Death."
</Sent>
<Sent id="4240">
	Text = "A very few French leagues of his journey were accomplished, when Charles Darnay began to perceive that for him along these country roads there was no hope of return until he should have been declared a good citizen at Paris."
</Sent>
<Sent id="4241">
	Text = "Whatever might befall now, he must on to his journey=s end."
</Sent>
<Sent id="4242">

<Sent id="4243">
	Text = "The universal watchfulness so encompassed him, that if he had been taken in a net, or were being forwarded to his destination in a cage, he could not have felt his freedom more completely gone."
</Sent>
<Sent id="4244">
	Text = "This universal watchfulness not only stopped him on the highway twenty times in a stage, but retarded his progress twenty times in a day, by riding after him and taking him back, riding before him and stopping him by anticipation, riding with him and keeping him in charge."
</Sent>

<Sent id="4675">
	Text = "The new era began the king was tried, doomed, and beheaded the Republic of Liberty, Equality, Fraternity, or Death, declared for victory or death against the world in arms the black flag waved night and day from the great towers of Notre Dame three hundred thousand men, summoned to rise against the tyrants of the earth, rose from all the varying soils of France, as if the dragon=s teeth had been sown broadcast, and had yielded fruit equally on hill and plain, on rock, in gravel, and alluvial mud, under the bright sky of the South and under the clouds of the North, in fell and forest, in the vineyards and the olive-grounds and among the cropped grass and the stubble of the corn, along the fruitful banks of the broad rivers, and in the sand of the sea-shore."

<Sent id="5589">
	Text = "“I, Alexandre Manette, unfortunate physician, native of Beauvais, and afterwards resident in Paris, write this melancholy paper in my doleful cell in the Bastille, during the last month of the year, 1767."

<Sent id="5590">
	Text = "I write it at stolen intervals, under every difficulty."

<Sent id="5593">

</Sent>
<Sent id="5594">
	Text = "Hope has quite departed from my breast."

<Sent id="5595">

</Sent>
<Sent id="5596">
	Text = "“One cloudy moonlight night, in the third week of December I think the twenty-second of the month in the year 1757, I was walking on a retired part of the quay by the Seine for the refreshment of the frosty air, at an hour=s distance from my place of residence in the Street of the School of Medicine, when a carriage came along behind me, driven very fast."

<Sent id="6173">
	Text = "CHAPTER XIII."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6174">
	Text = "Fifty-two In the black prison of the Conciergerie, the doomed of the day awaited their fate."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6175">
	Text = "They were in number as the weeks of the year."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6176">
	Text = "Fifty-two were to roll that afternoon on the life-tide of the city to the boundless everlasting sea."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6177">
	Text = "Before their cells were quit of them, new occupants were appointed before their blood ran into the blood spilled yesterday, the blood that was to mingle with theirs to-morrow was already set apart."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6178">
	Text = "Two score and twelve were told off."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6179">
	Text = "From the farmer-general of seventy, whose riches could not buy his life, to the seamstress of twenty, whose poverty and obscurity could not save her."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6180">
	Text = "Physical diseases, engendered in the vices and neglects of men, will seize on victims of all degrees and the frightful moral disorder, born of unspeakable suffering, intolerable oppression, and heartless indifference, smote equally without distinction."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6181">
	Text = "Charles Darnay, alone in a cell, had sustained himself with no flattering delusion since he came to it from the Tribunal."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6182">
	Text = "In every line of the narrative he had heard, he had heard his condemnation."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6183">
	Text = "He had fully comprehended that no personal influence could possibly save him, that he was virtually sentenced by the millions, and that units could avail him nothing."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6184">
	Text = "Nevertheless, it was not easy, with the face of his beloved wife fresh before him, to compose his mind to what it must bear."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6185">
	Text = "His hold on life was strong, and it was very, very hard, to loosen by gradual efforts and degrees unclosed a little here, it clenched the tighter there and when he brought his strength to bear on that hand and it yielded, this was closed again."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6186">
	Text = "There was a hurry, too, in all his thoughts, a turbulent and heated working of his heart, that contended against resignation."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6187">
	Text = "If, for a moment, he did feel resigned, then his wife and child who had to live after him, seemed to protest and to make it a selfish thing."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6188">
	Text = "But, all this was at first."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6189">
	Text = "Before long, the consideration that there was no disgrace in the fate he must meet, and that numbers went the same road wrongfully, and trod it firmly every day, sprang up to stimulate him."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6190">
	Text = "Next followed the thought that much of the future peace of mind enjoyable by the dear ones, depended on his quiet fortitude."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6191">
	Text = "So, by degrees he calmed into the better state, when he could raise his thoughts much higher, and draw comfort down."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6192">
	Text = "Before it had set in dark on the night of his condemnation, he had travelled thus far on his last way."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6193">
	Text = "Being allowed to purchase the means of writing, and a light, he sat down to write until such time as the prison lamps should be extinguished."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6194">
	Text = "He wrote a long letter to Lucie, showing her that he had known nothing of her father=s imprisonment, until he had heard of it from herself, and that he had been as ignorant as she of his father=s and uncle=s responsibility for that misery, until the paper had been read."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6195">
	Text = "He had already explained to her that his concealment from herself of the name he had relinquished, was the one condition-- fully intelligible now-- that her father had attached to their betrothal, and was the one promise he had still exacted on the morning of their marriage."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6196">
	Text = "He entreated her, for her father=s sake, never to seek to know whether her father had become oblivious of the existence of the paper, or had had it recalled to him for the moment, or for good, by the story of the Tower, on that old Sunday under the dear old plane-tree in the garden."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6197">
	Text = "If he had preserved any definite remembrance of it, there could be no doubt that he had supposed it destroyed with the Bastille, when he had found no mention of it among the relics of prisoners which the populace had discovered there, and which had been described to all the world."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6198">
	Text = "He besought her-- though he added that he knew it was needless-- to console her father, by impressing him through every tender means she could think of, with the truth that he had done nothing for which he could justly reproach himself, but had uniformly forgotten himself for their joint sakes."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6199">
	Text = "Next to her preservation of his own last grateful love and blessing, and her overcoming of her sorrow, to devote herself to their dear child, he adjured her, as they would meet in Heaven, to comfort her father."

</Sent>
<Sent id="6719">
	Text = "“If thou be changed into this shape by the will of God,” say the seers to the enchanted, in the wise Arabian stories, “then remain so! But, if thou wear this form through mere passing conjuration, then resume thy former aspect!” Changeless and hopeless, the tumbrils roll along."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6720">
	Text = "As the sombre wheels of the six carts go round, they seem to plough up a long crooked furrow among the populace in the streets."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6721">
	Text = "Ridges of faces are thrown to this side and to that, and the ploughs go steadily onward."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6722">
	Text = "So used are the regular inhabitants of the houses to the spectacle, that in many windows there are no people, and in some the occupation of the hands is not so much as suspended, while the eyes survey the faces in the tumbrils."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6723">
	Text = "Here and there, the inmate has visitors to see the sight then he points his finger, with something of the complacency of a curator or authorised exponent, to this cart and to this, and seems to tell who sat here yesterday, and who there the day before."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6724">
	Text = "Of the riders in the tumbrils, some observe these things, and all things on their last roadside, with an impassive stare others, with a lingering interest in the ways of life and men."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6725">
	Text = "Some, seated with drooping heads, are sunk in silent despair again, there are some so heedful of their looks that they cast upon the multitude such glances as they have seen in theatres, and in pictures."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6726">
	Text = "Several close their eyes, and think, or try to get their straying thoughts together."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6727">
	Text = "Only one, and he a miserable creature, of a crazed aspect, is so shattered and made drunk by horror, that he sings, and tries to dance."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6728">
	Text = "Not one of the whole number appeals by look or gesture, to the pity of the people."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6729">
	Text = "There is a guard of sundry horsemen riding abreast of the tumbrils, and faces are often turned up to some of them, and they are asked some question."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6730">
	Text = "It would seem to be always the same question, for, it is always followed by a press of people towards the third cart."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6731">
	Text = "The horsemen abreast of that cart, frequently point out one man in it with their swords."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6732">
	Text = "The leading curiosity is, to know which is he he stands at the back of the tumbril with his head bent down, to converse with a mere girl who sits on the side of the cart, and holds his hand."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6733">
	Text = "He has no curiosity or care for the scene about him, and always speaks to the girl."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6734">
	Text = "Here and there in the long street of St Honore, cries are raised against him."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6735">
	Text = "If they move him at all, it is only to a quiet smile, as he shakes his hair a little more loosely about his face."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6736">
	Text = "He cannot easily touch his face, his arms being bound."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6737">
	Text = "On the steps of a church, awaiting the coming-up of the tumbrils, stands the Spy and prison-sheep."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6738">
	Text = "He looks into the first of them not there."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6739">
	Text = "He looks into the second not there."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6740">
	Text = "He already asks himself, “Has he sacrificed me?"
</Sent>
<Sent id="6741">
	Text = "” when his face clears, as he looks into the third."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6742">
	Text = "“Which is Evrmonde?"
</Sent>
<Sent id="6743">
	Text = "” says a man behind him."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6744">
	Text = "“That."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6745">
	Text = "At the back there."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6746">
	Text = "” “With his hand in the girl=s?"
</Sent>
<Sent id="6747">
	Text = "” “Yes."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6748">
	Text = "” The man cries, “Down, Evrmonde! To the Guillotine all aristocrats! Down, Evrmonde!” “Hush, hush!” the Spy entreats him, timidly."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6749">
	Text = "“And why not, citizen?"
</Sent>
<Sent id="6750">
	Text = "” “He is going to pay the forfeit it will be paid in five minutes more."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6751">
	Text = "Let him be at peace."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6752">
	Text = "” But the man continuing to exclaim, “Down, Evrmonde!” the face of Evrmonde is for a moment turned towards him."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6753">
	Text = "Evrmonde then sees the Spy, and looks attentively at him, and goes his way."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6754">
	Text = "The clocks are on the stroke of three, and the furrow ploughed among the populace is turning round, to come on into the place of execution, and end."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6755">
	Text = "The ridges thrown to this side and to that, now crumble in and close behind the last plough as it passes on, for all are following to the Guillotine."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6756">
	Text = "In front of it, seated in chairs, as in a garden of public diversion, are a number of women, busily knitting."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6757">
	Text = "On one of the fore-most chairs, stands The Vengeance, looking about for her friend."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6758">
	Text = "“Thrse!” she cries, in her shrill tones."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6759">
	Text = "“Who has seen her?"
</Sent>
<Sent id="6760">
	Text = "Thrse Defarge!” “She never missed before,” says a knitting-woman of the sisterhood."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6761">
	Text = "“No nor will she miss now,” cries The Vengeance, petulantly."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6762">
	Text = "“Thrse."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6763">
	Text = "” “Louder,” the woman recommends."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6764">
	Text = "Ay! Louder, Vengeance, much louder, and still she will scarcely hear thee."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6765">
	Text = "Louder yet, Vengeance, with a little oath or so added, and yet it will hardly bring her."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6766">
	Text = "Send other women up and down to seek her, lingering somewhere and yet, although the messengers have done dread deeds, it is questionable whether of their own wills they will go far enough to find her! “Bad Fortune!” cries The Vengeance, stamping her foot in the chair, “and here are the tumbrils! And Evrmonde will be despatched in a wink, and she not here! See her knitting in my hand, and her empty chair ready for her."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6767">
	Text = "I cry with vexation and disappointment!” As The Vengeance descends from her elevation to do it, the tumbrils begin to discharge their loads."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6768">
	Text = "The ministers of Sainte Guillotine are robed and ready."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6769">
	Text = "Crash!-- A head is held up, and the knitting-women who scarcely lifted their eyes to look at it a moment ago when it could think and speak, count One."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6770">
	Text = "The second tumbril empties and moves on the third comes up."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6771">
	Text = "Crash!-- And the knitting-women, never faltering or pausing in their Work, count Two."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6772">
	Text = "The supposed Evrmonde descends, and the seamstress is lifted out next after him."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6773">
	Text = "He has not relinquished her patient hand in getting out, but still holds it as he promised."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6774">
	Text = "He gently places her with her back to the crashing engine that constantly whirrs up and falls, and she looks into his face and thanks him."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6775">
	Text = "“But for you, dear stranger, I should not be so composed, for I am naturally a poor little thing, faint of heart nor should I have been able to raise my thoughts to Him who was put to death, that we might have hope and comfort here to-day."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6776">
	Text = "I think you were sent to me by Heaven."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6777">
	Text = "” “Or you to me,” says Sydney Carton."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6778">
	Text = "“Keep your eyes upon me, dear child, and mind no other object."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6779">
	Text = "” “I mind nothing while I hold your hand."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6780">
	Text = "I shall mind nothing when I let it go, if they are rapid."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6781">
	Text = "” “They will be rapid."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6782">
	Text = "Fear not!” The two stand in the fast-thinning throng of victims, but they speak as if they were alone."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6783">
	Text = "Eye to eye, voice to voice, hand to hand, heart to heart, these two children of the Universal Mother, else so wide apart and differing, have come together on the dark highway, to repair home together, and to rest in her bosom."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6784">
	Text = "“Brave and generous friend, will you let me ask you one last question?"
</Sent>
<Sent id="6785">
	Text = "I am very ignorant, and it troubles me-- just a little."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6786">
	Text = "” “Tell me what it is."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6787">
	Text = "” “I have a cousin, an only relative and an orphan, like myself, whom I love very dearly."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6788">
	Text = "She is five years younger than I, and she lives in a farmer=s house in the south country."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6789">
	Text = "Poverty parted us, and she knows nothing of my fate-- for I cannot write-- and if I could, how should I tell her! It is better as it is."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6790">
	Text = "” “Yes, yes better as it is."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6791">
	Text = "” “What I have been thinking as we came along, and what I am still thinking now, as I look into your kind strong face which gives me so much support, is this-- If the Republic really does good to the poor, and they come to be less hungry, and in all ways to suffer less, she may live a long time she may even live to be old."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6792">
	Text = "” “What then, my gentle sister?"
</Sent>
<Sent id="6793">
	Text = "” “Do you think” the uncomplaining eyes in which there is so much endurance, fill with tears, and the lips part a little more and tremble “that it will seem long to me, while I wait for her in the better land where I trust both you and I will be mercifully sheltered?"
</Sent>
<Sent id="6794">
	Text = "” “It cannot be, my child there is no Time there, and no trouble there."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6795">
	Text = "” “You comfort me so much! I am so ignorant."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6796">
	Text = "Am I to kiss you now?"
</Sent>
<Sent id="6797">
	Text = "Is the moment come?"
</Sent>
<Sent id="6798">
	Text = "” “Yes."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6799">
	Text = "” She kisses his lips he kisses hers they solemnly bless each other."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6800">
	Text = "The spare hand does not tremble as he releases it nothing worse than a sweet, bright constancy is in the patient face."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6801">
	Text = "She goes next before him-- is gone the knitting-women count Twenty-Two."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6802">
	Text = "“I am the Resurrection and the Life, saith the Lord he that believeth in me, though he were dead, yet shall he live and whosoever liveth and believeth in me shall never die."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6803">
	Text = "” The murmuring of many voices, the upturning of many faces, the pressing on of many footsteps in the outskirts of the crowd, so that it swells forward in a mass, like one great heave of water, all flashes away."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6804">
	Text = "Twenty-Three."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6805">
	Text = "They said of him, about the city that night, that it was the peacefullest man=s face ever beheld there."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6806">
	Text = "Many added that he looked sublime and prophetic."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6807">
	Text = "One of the most remarkable sufferers by the same axe-- a woman-- had asked at the foot of the same scaffold, not long before, to be allowed to write down the thoughts that were inspiring her."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6808">
	Text = "If he had given any utterance to his, and they were prophetic, they would have been these “I see Barsad, and Cly, Defarge, The Vengeance, the Juryman, the Judge, long ranks of the new oppressors who have risen on the destruction of the old, perishing by this retributive instrument, before it shall cease out of its present use."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6809">
	Text = "I see a beautiful city and a brilliant people rising from this abyss, and, in their struggles to be truly free, in their triumphs and defeats, through long years to come, I see the evil of this time and of the previous time of which this is the natural birth, gradually making expiation for itself and wearing out."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6810">
	Text = "“I see the lives for which I lay down my life, peaceful, useful, prosperous and happy, in that England which I shall see no more."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6811">
	Text = "I see Her with a child upon her bosom, who bears my name."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6812">
	Text = "I see her father, aged and bent, but otherwise restored, and faithful to all men in his healing office, and at peace."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6813">
	Text = "I see the good old man, so long their friend, in ten years’ time enriching them with all he has, and passing tranquilly to his reward."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6814">
	Text = "“I see that I hold a sanctuary in their hearts, and in the hearts of their descendants, generations hence."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6815">
	Text = "I see her, an old woman, weeping for me on the anniversary of this day."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6816">
	Text = "I see her and her husband, their course done, lying side by side in their last earthly bed, and I know that each was not more honoured and held sacred in the other=s soul, than I was in the souls of both."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6817">
	Text = "“I see that child who lay upon her bosom and who bore my name, a man winning his way up in that path of life which once was mine."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6818">
	Text = "I see him winning it so well, that my name is made illustrious there by the light of his."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6819">
	Text = "I see the blots I threw upon it, faded away."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6820">
	Text = "I see him, fore-most of just judges and honoured men, bringing a boy of my name, with a forehead that I know and golden hair, to this place-- then fair to look upon, with not a trace of this day=s disfigurement-- and I hear him tell the child my story, with a tender and a faltering voice."
</Sent>
<Sent id="6821">
	Text = "“It is a far, far better thing that I do, than I have ever done it is a far, far better rest that I go to than I have ever known."
</Sent>
